don't like dogs to warm up too much this
is Mary Pollan sports reporter for The
New York Times it's been an unusually
warm winter in Willow Alaska on some
days the temperature hovers around 30
degrees well above normal this is bad
news for luan Marquez and his team of
sled dogs who are training for the
Iditarod the annual 1,000 mile dogsled
race across Alaska it has been rainy
season we had pretty much no snow
the trails are nice and modern so there
are some races being canceled the
connection hunter was canceled the
downbar s200 was cancelled to qualify
for the idea to rod teams must compete
in shorter races a year in advance which
means this year it'll be difficult for
rookies to qualify even experienced
mushers are having trouble getting
enough practice trainings one of those
challenges you know you know you got to
get you know we were lucky we got that
Copper Basin race and it rained heavy
during the race one night we were
traveling it's a kind of a challenge to
put on a happy face when it's Porter
Thank You
mushers are now taking protective
measures like making more stops while
training so that their dogs don't
overheat they also worry their dogs will
be injured as paws slide on rough ice
rather than a cross soft snow some
mushers have even begun breeding dogs
with shorter fur to adapt to climate
change
but cold weather or not some dedicated
mushers say the race must go on we work
really hard they no matter what the
weather is we can figure out a way to do
something with it
